curam.util.exception
Class AppException

java.lang.Object
  java.lang.Throwable
      java.lang.Exception
          curam.util.exception.AppException
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
public class AppException
extends java.lang.Exception

AppException is commonly thrown in Curam applications to indicate a condition that the calling code might wish to handle. In general, all checked Curam exceptions are instances of AppException. Every business object method declaration includes AppException in its "throws" clause.

You catch AppExceptions when you want to add some context-specific information by throwing your own exception instance. As a rule of thumb, if you are not adding any more specific information, don't bother catching the exception . If you are catching an exception, but don't wish to lose stack trace and other information about the exception, you can chain the caught exception on to the new one that you create and throw.

AppExceptions have message text associated with them. Rather than specifying the text directly when you instantiate AppException, a reference to an entry in a message catalog is used. The reference is a constant value generated by Curam based on message catalog definitions in a ".msg" file. Message Catalogs allow messages to be localized. The message text can also have "placeholders" associated with it, replaced at runtime with arguments that you add to the exception.

Placeholders can appear anywhere in the message text and are introduced by a percent character e.g.: "This is the text of message number %1n"

Placeholders are of the form: `%nc`, where n is a number (of 1 or more digits), and c is a single character denoting the argument type as follows:

  • s - string
  • n - numeric
  • d - date
  • t - time
  • z - date/time
  • c - code item
The `\` character can be used as an escape character anywhere in the message text, and must be used whenever the message text needs to contain a percent sign `\%`, or a backslash `\\`.

The code item is treated separately from a string to allow for localization in the client. Code Items are returned in the text of an exception as <TableName>:<Code>. This ensures that the client can present the associated description in the correct language for the user.

In your code, you provide arguments to replace placeholders with the "arg" methods of AppException. Here's an example: AppException e = new AppException(MY_CATALOG.MYEXCEPTION); e.arg("some text"); e.arg(25); throw e; Because the "arg" methods return a reference to the AppException, the above is equivalent to the following shorthand:

throw (new AppException(MY_CATALOG.MYEXCEPTION)).arg("some text"). arg(25);

The order in which you add arguments determines which placeholders they replace -- the first argument replaces the placeholder with number 1, the second replaces number 2, and so on. This means that localized versions of messages can have placeholders which do not appear in the same order as the non-localized ones.

It should be noted that if a string is provided as an argument where a code table is specified then the string will be output. If a code table is used as an argument where a string is specified then the code table will be output.

AppRuntimeException, Serialized Form

getArguments

public java.util.ArrayList getArguments()
Return the ArrayList list of arguments for the exception.

Returns:
ArrayList of the arguments that have been added to the exception, in the order they have been added. If no args have been added the ArrayList will have a size of zero.

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object rightHandSide)
Compare this AppException to another object.

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
rightHandSide - Object to compare to.
Returns:
True if the specified object is an instance of AppException based on the same catalog entry, false otherwise. This equality operator does not take into account the arguments or the context (i.e. the stack trace) associated with the exception when determining equality.

setLoggable

public void setLoggable(boolean indicator)
Indicate whether the exception should be automatically logged if thrown from an online function. When this flag is set, the exception and all its chained exceptions will be logged to a file or the console unless a higher level caller catches and discards the exception. Set this flag for serious exceptions that should be notified to a system administrator, rather than just to the end user. When an exception has a chain of linked exceptions, all of the exceptions in the chain are logged if any one of the items in the chain has this flag set.

Parameters:
indicator - Flag to tell whether the exception should be logged.

isLoggable

public boolean isLoggable()
Check whether the exception would be logged if thrown from an online function.

Returns:
True if the exception or any of its chained exceptions should be logged, otherwise false

getLog

public java.lang.String getLog()

A String containing the stack trace.

public java.lang.String toString()

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Throwable
Returns:
The extended message text. If the text associated with the exception exceeds 4K (4096 bytes) it is truncated to this size.

getMessage

public java.lang.String getMessage()
Get the text associated with the exception in the default server locale. The basic text is loaded from a Message Catalog, and any placeholders in the text are replaced with arguments attached to the AppException instance.

Overrides:
getMessage in class java.lang.Throwable
Returns:
String which has the placeholders updated with the actual arguments. If the string exceeds 4K (4096 bytes) it is truncated to this size.

getMessage

Parameters:
locale - specified locale.
Returns:
String which has the placeholders updated with the actual arguments. If the string exceeds 4K (4096 bytes) it is truncated to this size.
